issue.title: Intelligent edge case detection and specialized handling
issue.body:
## Problem
Electronic music collections contain diverse content that breaks standard album organization:
- **Live mixes & radio shows**: Single long files (1-6 hours) that aren't albums
- **Label compilations**: Massive releases (10+ hours) functioning as label showcases
- **DJ sets & live recordings**: Historical artefacts requiring special preservation
- **Podcast archives**: Radio shows, Essential Mixes, BBC sessions with uncertain value
- **Bootlegs & unofficial**: Gray area content requiring careful handling
- **Multi-format releases**: Same content across vinyl, digital, CD with different track divisions

Current album-based logic fails catastrophically on these edge cases.

## Solution
Implement intelligent edge case detection that:
- **Automatically identifies** unusual content patterns
- **Categorizes edge cases** with appropriate handling strategies  
- **Preserves context** for future value assessment
- **Enables flexible organization** beyond standard album structure
- **Provides user choice** on handling strategies per edge case type

## Edge Case Detection Patterns

### **Duration Analysis**
- **Single file > 60 minutes**: Likely DJ mix, radio show, or live recording
- **Album > 4 hours**: Probably label compilation or multi-disc special
- **Track count vs duration mismatch**: Indicates mix CDs or live content

### **Content Pattern Recognition**
- **Mix/Set/Live keywords**: "Essential Mix", "Live at", "DJ Set", "Radio Show"
- **Label showcase patterns**: "10 Years of [Label]", "Label Sampler"
- **Series indicators**: "Volume", "Part", "Session", "Episode"
- **Bootleg/Unofficial markers**: "Unreleased", "White Label", "Promo"

### **Metadata Anomalies**
- **Missing standard tags**: No album artist, inconsistent naming
- **Unusual track numbering**: Continuous mix track markers
- **Date inconsistencies**: Spanning multiple years/decades
- **Quality variations**: Suggesting different sources/rips

## Specialized Handling Strategies

### **DJ Mixes & Radio Shows**
```
Archive/
â”œâ”€â”€ Essential Mixes/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ [1993-10-30] Sasha - Essential Mix/
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ [2001-12-15] Carl Cox - Essential Mix/
â”œâ”€â”€ Label Showcases/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ Warp Records - Artificial Intelligence Series/
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ R&S Records - The Classics/
â”œâ”€â”€ Live Recordings/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ [1989] Orbital - Live at Glastonbury/
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ [1995] The Orb - Live in Concert/
```

### **Preservation Categories**
- **Historical Significance**: Classic radio shows, legendary sets
- **Personal Archive**: Personal recordings, rare finds
- **Reference Material**: Genre overviews, label histories
- **Uncertain Value**: Content requiring future assessment

## Implementation Features

### **Smart Detection**
- `--detect-edge-cases` flag for analysis mode
- Pattern matching with confidence scoring
- Machine learning from user feedback over time
- Configurable detection sensitivity

### **Flexible Organization**
- `--edge-case-strategy <preserve|archive|organize>` 
- Custom organization patterns per edge case type
- Metadata preservation with context annotations
- User review queue for uncertain classifications

### **Context Preservation**
- **Source tracking**: Where/when content was acquired
- **Significance markers**: User-defined importance levels
- **Relationship mapping**: Connections to main collection
- **Access frequency**: Usage patterns for value assessment

## Use Cases

### **DJ/Producer Collections**
- Preserving mix archives with proper dating and context
- Organizing reference material vs active collection
- Maintaining bootleg/promo sections with provenance

### **Label Enthusiasts**
- Handling massive compilation releases appropriately
- Organizing label history and milestone releases
- Managing different formats of same conceptual release

### **Music Historians/Archivists**
- Preserving radio show archives with cultural context
- Maintaining chronological access to scene evolution
- Balancing preservation vs active collection needs

## Advanced Features

### **Value Assessment Engine**
- Historical significance scoring
- Rarity and availability analysis
- Personal preference learning
- Storage cost vs value analysis

### **Relationship Intelligence**
- Cross-referencing artists across edge cases
- Label network mapping from various sources
- Genre evolution tracking through time
- Influence and reference relationship detection

## Configuration Examples
```bash
# Conservative approach - preserve everything with context
./ordr.fm.sh --detect-edge-cases --edge-case-strategy preserve

# Archival approach - separate organization for edge cases  
./ordr.fm.sh --edge-case-strategy archive --archive-uncertain

# Active curation - user review for edge case handling
./ordr.fm.sh --edge-case-strategy organize --review-queue
```

## Priority
High - Electronic music collections are defined by their edge cases. Without proper handling, the tool fails for serious collectors.

## Success Criteria
- Accurately detects 90%+ of edge cases without false positives
- Provides appropriate organization strategies for each edge case type
- Preserves enough context for future value assessment
- Handles uncertainty gracefully with user input options

comment.body:
âœ… **IMPLEMENTED** - Intelligent edge case detection for electronic music collections

**Implementation Details:**
- Pattern recognition for DJ mixes, radio shows, live performances, and massive compilations
- Duration analysis with file size estimation for classification
- Keyword matching for electronic music content types
- Flexible handling strategies: preserve, archive, organize, review
- Context preservation with annotation markers

**Edge Case Types Detected:**
- **DJ Mix/Radio Show**: Single long files (>1hr) with mix/radio keywords
- **Massive Compilation**: Multi-hour releases or large track counts (10+ hours)
- **Live Performance**: Live keywords with extended duration content
- **Series Content**: Numbered episodes/sessions (Essential Mix series, etc.)
- **Label Showcase**: Large collections without standard compilation markers

**Key Functions:**
- `detect_edge_case()` - Intelligent classification algorithm (lines 250-369)
- `get_edge_case_description()` - Human-readable descriptions (lines 371-409)
- `handle_edge_case()` - Strategy-based handling (lines 411-467)
- Integrated into main processing before metadata extraction (lines 972-983)

**Usage:**
```bash
# Enable edge case detection with preservation
./ordr.fm.sh --detect-edge-cases --edge-case-strategy preserve

# Archive edge cases separately  
./ordr.fm.sh --edge-case-strategy archive

# Review queue for manual decisions
./ordr.fm.sh --edge-case-strategy review
```

**Electronic Music Intelligence:**
- Recognizes Essential Mix archives and BBC sessions
- Handles 10+ hour label compilation releases properly
- Preserves DJ mix context and historical significance
- Supports review workflow for uncertain content classification

**Production Benefits:**
- Critical for serious electronic music collections
- Prevents misorganization of historical archives
- Maintains context for culturally significant content
- Enables flexible handling based on collection goals

issue.title: Intelligent edge case detection and specialized handling
issue.body:
## Problem
Electronic music collections contain diverse content that breaks standard album organization:
- **Live mixes & radio shows**: Single long files (1-6 hours) that aren't albums
- **Label compilations**: Massive releases (10+ hours) functioning as label showcases
- **DJ sets & live recordings**: Historical artefacts requiring special preservation
- **Podcast archives**: Radio shows, Essential Mixes, BBC sessions with uncertain value
- **Bootlegs & unofficial**: Gray area content requiring careful handling
- **Multi-format releases**: Same content across vinyl, digital, CD with different track divisions

Current album-based logic fails catastrophically on these edge cases.

## Solution
Implement intelligent edge case detection that:
- **Automatically identifies** unusual content patterns
- **Categorizes edge cases** with appropriate handling strategies  
- **Preserves context** for future value assessment
- **Enables flexible organization** beyond standard album structure
- **Provides user choice** on handling strategies per edge case type

## Edge Case Detection Patterns

### **Duration Analysis**
- **Single file > 60 minutes**: Likely DJ mix, radio show, or live recording
- **Album > 4 hours**: Probably label compilation or multi-disc special
- **Track count vs duration mismatch**: Indicates mix CDs or live content

### **Content Pattern Recognition**
- **Mix/Set/Live keywords**: "Essential Mix", "Live at", "DJ Set", "Radio Show"
- **Label showcase patterns**: "10 Years of [Label]", "Label Sampler"
- **Series indicators**: "Volume", "Part", "Session", "Episode"
- **Bootleg/Unofficial markers**: "Unreleased", "White Label", "Promo"

### **Metadata Anomalies**
- **Missing standard tags**: No album artist, inconsistent naming
- **Unusual track numbering**: Continuous mix track markers
- **Date inconsistencies**: Spanning multiple years/decades
- **Quality variations**: Suggesting different sources/rips

## Specialized Handling Strategies

### **DJ Mixes & Radio Shows**
```
Archive/
â”œâ”€â”€ Essential Mixes/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ [1993-10-30] Sasha - Essential Mix/
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ [2001-12-15] Carl Cox - Essential Mix/
â”œâ”€â”€ Label Showcases/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ Warp Records - Artificial Intelligence Series/
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ R&S Records - The Classics/
â”œâ”€â”€ Live Recordings/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ [1989] Orbital - Live at Glastonbury/
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ [1995] The Orb - Live in Concert/
```

### **Preservation Categories**
- **Historical Significance**: Classic radio shows, legendary sets
- **Personal Archive**: Personal recordings, rare finds
- **Reference Material**: Genre overviews, label histories
- **Uncertain Value**: Content requiring future assessment

## Implementation Features

### **Smart Detection**
- `--detect-edge-cases` flag for analysis mode
- Pattern matching with confidence scoring
- Machine learning from user feedback over time
- Configurable detection sensitivity

### **Flexible Organization**
- `--edge-case-strategy <preserve|archive|organize>` 
- Custom organization patterns per edge case type
- Metadata preservation with context annotations
- User review queue for uncertain classifications

### **Context Preservation**
- **Source tracking**: Where/when content was acquired
- **Significance markers**: User-defined importance levels
- **Relationship mapping**: Connections to main collection
- **Access frequency**: Usage patterns for value assessment

## Use Cases

### **DJ/Producer Collections**
- Preserving mix archives with proper dating and context
- Organizing reference material vs active collection
- Maintaining bootleg/promo sections with provenance

### **Label Enthusiasts**
- Handling massive compilation releases appropriately
- Organizing label history and milestone releases
- Managing different formats of same conceptual release

### **Music Historians/Archivists**
- Preserving radio show archives with cultural context
- Maintaining chronological access to scene evolution
- Balancing preservation vs active collection needs

## Advanced Features

### **Value Assessment Engine**
- Historical significance scoring
- Rarity and availability analysis
- Personal preference learning
- Storage cost vs value analysis

### **Relationship Intelligence**
- Cross-referencing artists across edge cases
- Label network mapping from various sources
- Genre evolution tracking through time
- Influence and reference relationship detection

## Configuration Examples
```bash
# Conservative approach - preserve everything with context
./ordr.fm.sh --detect-edge-cases --edge-case-strategy preserve

# Archival approach - separate organization for edge cases  
./ordr.fm.sh --edge-case-strategy archive --archive-uncertain

# Active curation - user review for edge case handling
./ordr.fm.sh --edge-case-strategy organize --review-queue
```

## Priority
High - Electronic music collections are defined by their edge cases. Without proper handling, the tool fails for serious collectors.

## Success Criteria
- Accurately detects 90%+ of edge cases without false positives
- Provides appropriate organization strategies for each edge case type
- Preserves enough context for future value assessment
- Handles uncertainty gracefully with user input options

issue.title: Enhanced progress reporting for headless operations
issue.body:
## Problem
When running on headless devices (Raspberry Pi, NAS), users have limited visibility into processing progress, especially for large collections that may run for hours or days.

## Solution
Implement comprehensive progress reporting that:
- Shows processing progress with ETA estimates
- Reports current file/album being processed
- Displays throughput statistics (albums/hour, files/hour)
- Provides milestone notifications (every 100 albums, hourly updates)
- Offers multiple output formats (console, log file, status file)

## Features
- `--progress-interval` to control update frequency
- `--status-file` for external monitoring scripts
- Progress indicators compatible with headless operation
- Memory usage and performance metrics
- Configurable notification thresholds

## Use Cases
- Monitoring long-running operations via SSH
- Integration with home automation systems
- Alerting when processing completes
- Performance tuning for optimal Pi/NAS operation

## Technical Details
- Non-blocking progress updates
- Minimal performance overhead
- Compatible with existing verbosity levels
- JSON status output for programmatic access

## Priority
Medium - Quality of life improvement for production deployments

issue.title: Resume interrupted operations for large music collections
issue.body:
## Problem
When processing large music collections on resource-constrained devices (Raspberry Pi, NAS), operations may be interrupted by reboots, power issues, or long processing times. Currently, the entire operation must restart from the beginning.

## Solution
Implement resume capability that:
- Tracks processing state in a resume file
- Skips already-processed directories on restart
- Handles partial album processing gracefully
- Provides clear indication of resume vs fresh start

## Use Cases
- Large music library processing on Raspberry Pi (10,000+ albums)
- NAS environments with automatic maintenance reboots
- Network storage with intermittent connectivity issues
- Multi-day processing jobs for massive collections

## Implementation
- `--resume` flag to continue from last checkpoint
- `.ordr_fm_state` file tracking completed directories
- Automatic detection of incomplete operations
- Safe cleanup of partial processing

## Priority
High - Critical for production use on resource-constrained devices

issue.title: MusicBrainz integration for comprehensive electronic music metadata
issue.body:
## Problem
Electronic music often lacks comprehensive metadata coverage in commercial databases. MusicBrainz provides the most complete open database for electronic music, including underground releases, proper remix credits, and detailed relationship data.

## Solution
Implement MusicBrainz API integration specifically optimized for electronic music that:
- Provides comprehensive metadata for underground and mainstream electronic releases
- Handles complex electronic music relationships (remixers, producers, collaborators)
- Offers accurate genre/tag data from community contributions
- Supports release group relationships for different formats of same release
- Integrates with existing Discogs enrichment for maximum coverage

## MusicBrainz Advantages for Electronic Music
### **Comprehensive Coverage**
- Extensive underground label coverage
- Detailed remix and collaboration credits
- Multiple release formats (12", digital, CD) linked properly
- Community-driven accuracy for niche genres

### **Relationship Data**
- Producer, remixer, engineer, and collaborator credits
- Label and series relationships
- Original vs remix vs edit relationships
- Release group hierarchies (album â†’ singles â†’ remixes)

### **Genre/Tag Accuracy**
- Community-maintained electronic subgenre tags
- Accurate tempo and key information where available
- Mood and style tags specific to electronic music
- Era and movement tagging (Detroit techno, UK garage, etc.)

## Features
- `--musicbrainz-enrich` flag for MusicBrainz metadata lookup
- Multi-source enrichment strategy (MusicBrainz + Discogs fallback)
- Release group analysis for complete discography mapping
- Advanced relationship extraction:
  - Original artist vs remixer distinction
  - Producer and engineer credits
  - Label and sublabel relationships
  - Series and compilation memberships
- Community tag integration for genre accuracy
- Rate-limited API with respectful usage patterns

## Electronic Music Specific Enhancements
### **Remix Chain Analysis**
- Original release â†’ remix releases mapping
- Remixer discography building
- Cross-referencing remix appearances

### **Label Network Mapping**
- Parent label vs sublabel relationships
- Label artist roster tracking
- Catalog number series validation

### **Genre Intelligence**
- Electronic subgenre accuracy (house, techno, drum & bass, etc.)
- Era-specific tagging (acid house, UK garage, minimal techno)
- Regional scene identification (Detroit, Berlin, UK, etc.)

## Integration Strategy
1. **Primary**: MusicBrainz lookup for comprehensive relationship data
2. **Secondary**: Discogs fallback for commercial release information
3. **Tertiary**: Last.fm for additional tag/genre data
4. **Validation**: Cross-reference between sources for accuracy

## Use Cases
- Academic electronic music archives requiring detailed metadata
- DJ collections needing accurate remix and producer credits
- Label discography completion projects
- Electronic music research and analysis
- Comprehensive genre and style organization

## Implementation
- Parallel API queries with intelligent caching
- Confidence scoring across multiple sources
- Conflict resolution between different metadata sources
- Preview mode for metadata changes before application
- Integration with electronic music organization modes

## Priority
Medium-High - Provides the most comprehensive metadata source for serious electronic music collections

issue.title: Advanced electronic music organization with label series and remix handling
issue.body:
## Problem
Electronic music has unique organizational needs that standard album-based organization doesn't handle well:
- Label series (Kompakt Pop Ambient, Fabric mix series, Essential Mix compilations)
- Complex remix structures with multiple artists per track
- 12" singles with A/B side organization
- Compilation albums with individual track organization needs
- Underground label catalog numbering systems

## Solution
Implement electronic music specific organization patterns that:
- Recognize and organize label series systematically
- Handle remix artist attribution and organization
- Support vinyl-style A/B side organization for 12" singles
- Provide compilation track organization options
- Support underground label catalog patterns

## Electronic Music Features
### **Label Series Organization**
- Automatic series detection (e.g., "KOMPAKT 001", "FABRIC 150", "GOTT 001")
- Series-based organization: `Label Series/[SeriesNum] Artist - Title`
- Configurable series patterns for different label styles
- Series completion tracking and gap identification

### **Remix and Collaboration Handling**
- Intelligent remix artist extraction: "Artist - Track (Remixer Remix)"
- Multi-artist compilation organization
- Featured artist standardization
- Producer vs remixer vs vocalist distinction

### **Vinyl 12" Organization**
- A/B side detection and organization
- Track position preservation (A1, A2, B1, B2)
- Extended mix vs radio edit handling
- Multi-format organization (12", digital, CD)

### **Underground Label Support**
- Flexible catalog numbering patterns
- White label and promo handling
- Bootleg and unofficial release identification
- Limited edition and special release tagging

## Organization Examples
```

Lossless/
```

issue.title: Intelligent metadata enrichment via Discogs API
issue.body:
## Problem
Electronic music collections often have incomplete or inconsistent metadata, especially from underground labels, vinyl rips, or rare releases. Manual metadata correction is time-consuming and prone to errors.

## Solution
Implement Discogs API integration for intelligent metadata enrichment that:
- Queries Discogs database for missing/incomplete metadata
- Matches releases using multiple strategies (catalog number, artist+title, barcode)
- Enriches metadata with accurate label, catalog number, year, genre information
- Handles electronic music specifics (remix credits, label series, compilation details)
- Provides confidence scoring for automatic vs manual review

## Features
- `--enrich-metadata` flag to enable Discogs lookup
- `--discogs-token <token>` for API authentication
- Multiple matching strategies with fallback options:
  - Exact catalog number match (highest confidence)
  - Artist + album title + year fuzzy matching
  - Barcode/UPC lookup for commercial releases
- Electronic music specific enhancements:
  - Remix artist extraction and standardization
  - Label series identification (Kompakt Pop Ambient, Warp Records, etc.)
  - Release format detection (12", EP, LP, compilation)
  - Genre/style tagging from Discogs taxonomy
- Confidence thresholds for automatic vs manual review
- Batch processing with rate limiting (API respectful)
- Metadata backup before enrichment

## Electronic Music Specific Benefits
- **Underground Labels**: Often well-documented on Discogs vs other services
- **Vinyl Rips**: Catalog numbers provide exact release identification
- **Remix Credits**: Proper attribution for remixers and collaborators
- **Label History**: Comprehensive label and series information
- **Genre Accuracy**: Electronic subgenre specificity (techno, house, ambient, etc.)

## Use Cases
- Enriching vinyl rip collections with proper metadata
- Standardizing metadata across different sources
- Adding missing catalog numbers for organization
- Correcting artist name variations and remix credits
- Enhancing genre tagging for electronic subgenres

## Implementation
- Rate-limited API calls (respecting Discogs limits)
- Caching to avoid duplicate lookups
- Metadata conflict resolution strategies
- Preview mode to review changes before applying
- Integration with existing --catalog organization mode

## Priority
High - Critical for electronic music collectors with incomplete metadata

issue.title: Cron-friendly automation and scheduling support
issue.body:
## Problem
Running ordr.fm in automated/scheduled environments (cron, systemd timers) requires better support for unattended operation and integration with system scheduling.

## Solution
Implement automation-friendly features that:
- Support fully unattended operation with sensible defaults
- Provide clear exit codes for script integration
- Handle common automation scenarios gracefully
- Offer configuration validation before processing
- Support notification and reporting for automated runs

## Features
- `--batch` mode for fully automated operation
- `--validate-config` to check configuration before processing
- `--notify <email/webhook>` for completion notifications  
- Standardized exit codes (0=success, 1=errors, 2=config issues)
- Automated log rotation and cleanup
- Quiet mode with minimal output except errors
- Lock file support to prevent concurrent runs

## Automation Examples
```bash
# Daily processing of download folder
0 2 * * * /path/to/ordr.fm.sh --batch --incremental --source /downloads/music

# Weekly full validation run
0 3 * * 0 /path/to/ordr.fm.sh --batch --validate-config --performance
```

## Integration Features
- Systemd service file template
- Logrotate configuration example
- Health check endpoint/file for monitoring
- Resource usage limits and monitoring
- Graceful shutdown on system signals

## Use Cases
- Automated processing of download folders
- Scheduled maintenance and validation runs
- Integration with home automation systems
- Unattended operation on headless devices
- Batch processing during off-peak hours

## Priority
Medium - Essential for production automation on Pi/NAS environments

issue.title: Incremental processing for changed/new files only
issue.body:
## Problem
Re-processing entire music collections is time-consuming and unnecessary when only a few new albums have been added. Currently, there's no way to process only new or changed content.

## Solution
Implement incremental processing that:
- Tracks processed files/directories with timestamps
- Identifies new content since last run
- Detects moved or renamed files to avoid reprocessing
- Handles both new additions and structural changes
- Provides fast incremental scan mode

## Features
- `--incremental` flag for incremental-only processing
- `--since <date>` to process files newer than specified date
- Intelligent file tracking with checksums or modification times
- Fast directory scanning to identify changes
- Database of previously processed content
- Option to force reprocessing of specific directories

## Use Cases
- Daily/weekly automated processing of download folders
- Quick integration of newly ripped CDs
- Maintenance processing after manual file operations
- Efficient processing of large, stable collections with occasional additions

## Technical Implementation
- Lightweight tracking database (SQLite or JSON)
- Modification time comparison for change detection
- Configurable change detection sensitivity
- Safe handling of moved/renamed content

## Benefits
- Dramatically faster processing for established collections
- Suitable for automated/scheduled operation
- Reduced wear on storage devices (especially important for Pi/NAS)
- Lower resource usage for maintenance operations

## Priority
Medium - Significant performance improvement for ongoing collection management

issue.title: Configuration profiles for different music sources
issue.body:
## Problem
Users often have different organizational needs for different music sources (purchased music, ripped CDs, downloads, vinyl rips) but currently must use the same configuration for all processing.

## Solution
Implement configuration profiles that:
- Support multiple named configurations (e.g., 'vinyl', 'purchases', 'downloads')
- Allow different organization schemes per source type
- Enable source-specific quality handling and naming conventions
- Provide easy profile switching via command line

## Features
- `--profile <name>` to select configuration profile
- `--list-profiles` to show available configurations  
- Profile-specific settings for:
  - Directory organization patterns
  - Quality classification rules
  - Catalog number handling preferences
  - Subsidiary file organization
- Default profile fallback behavior

## Use Cases
- Vinyl rips: Different quality expectations and organization
- Purchased music: Preserve original catalog information
- Downloaded music: More aggressive duplicate detection
- Classical music: Different organizational requirements

## Configuration Example
```bash
# Vinyl profile - preserve all subsidiary files, looser quality rules
./ordr.fm.sh --profile vinyl --source /music/vinyl-rips

# Purchases profile - catalog number organization, strict quality
./ordr.fm.sh --profile purchases --catalog --source /music/purchases
```

## Priority
Medium - Enhances usability for advanced users with diverse collections

issue.title: Enhanced progress reporting for headless operations
issue.body:
## Problem
When running on headless devices (Raspberry Pi, NAS), users have limited visibility into processing progress, especially for large collections that may run for hours or days.

## Solution
Implement comprehensive progress reporting that:
- Shows processing progress with ETA estimates
- Reports current file/album being processed
- Displays throughput statistics (albums/hour, files/hour)
- Provides milestone notifications (every 100 albums, hourly updates)
- Offers multiple output formats (console, log file, status file)

## Features
- `--progress-interval` to control update frequency
- `--status-file` for external monitoring scripts
- Progress indicators compatible with headless operation
- Memory usage and performance metrics
- Configurable notification thresholds

## Use Cases
- Monitoring long-running operations via SSH
- Integration with home automation systems
- Alerting when processing completes
- Performance tuning for optimal Pi/NAS operation

## Technical Details
- Non-blocking progress updates
- Minimal performance overhead
- Compatible with existing verbosity levels
- JSON status output for programmatic access

## Priority
Medium - Quality of life improvement for production deployments
